title: GPEI-Enhancing Poliovirus Containment in the WHO Africa Region with Open Data Kit (ODK) - Global Polio Eradication Initiative
Sierra Leone declares public health emergency over mpox - The Times of India
Letting your dog lick your face can be dangerous: Study reveals potential health risk - Hindustan Times
summary:
Is your dog in the habit of licking your face? Study reveals how this may be dangerous for you.

Date: Jan 14, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

Many pet owners may not realize that allowing their dogs to lick their faces can pose significant health risks. A study from Pennsylvania State University highlights that household dogs can carry antibiotic-resistant strains of Salmonella.

  • Dogs may appear healthy but can carry harmful bacteria.
  • The study found 82 types of Salmonella in dogs examined from 2017 to 2023.
  • 39% of healthy dogs carry a gene (shdA) allowing them to harbor bacteria.
  • Humans can be exposed to Salmonella through saliva when dogs lick their faces.
“This reminds us that simple hygiene practices such as hand washing are needed to protect both our furry friends and ourselves.” - Nkuchia M’ikanatha

Researchers emphasize maintaining good hygiene after interacting with dogs and advise pet owners to avoid kissing their dogs on the lips or allowing them to lick their faces.
newTitle: Study Warns Against Letting Dogs Lick Faces Due to Health Risks

title: Eye’s retina offers non-invasive stroke risk prediction: study - BusinessLine
summary:
Eye’s Retina Offers Non-Invasive Stroke Risk Prediction: Study

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: The Hindu Business Line

Blood vessels in the eye's retina can help predict the risk of stroke as accurately as known risk factors, without requiring invasive lab tests, according to a recent study.

  • The study analyzed 68,753 fundus images to identify 29 retinal health indicators.
  • Nearly 750 strokes were reported over an average follow-up period of 12.5 years.
  • Identified a 'vascular fingerprint' that correlates with stroke risk.
  • More than half of the indicators relate to the density of blood vessels.
  • Non-invasive retinal analysis outperformed traditional risk assessment models.
“Retinal vascular analysis, a non-invasive screening approach for stroke risk assessment, performed better than traditional risk stratification models.”

This innovative approach could transform how stroke risk is assessed, especially in primary healthcare and resource-limited settings.
newTitle: Eye's Retina Offers Non-Invasive Stroke Risk Prediction: Study

title: Comparative analysis of C-Reactive protein levels among Non-comorbid, Comorbid, and Multimorbid Hospitalized COVID-19 patients - BMC Infectious Diseases
summary:
Comparative analysis of C-Reactive protein levels among Non-comorbid, Comorbid, and Multimorbid Hospitalized COVID-19 patients

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This research evaluates serum C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in different categories of hospitalized COVID-19 patients to understand how comorbidities influence inflammation and disease severity.

  • 618 hospitalized COVID-19 patients analyzed, with varying comorbidity status.
  • Patients with diabetes and hypertension exhibited significantly higher CRP levels.
  • CRP levels averaged 88.92 mg/L, with significant variations observed among age groups and comorbidities.
  • Cox regression analysis indicated that each 1-unit increase in CRP levels correlated with a greater length of hospital stay.
“Elevated CRP levels in COVID-19 patients with comorbidities were strongly associated with increased disease severity.”

This study highlights the importance of monitoring CRP as a biomarker in managing COVID-19, especially among patients with underlying health issues.
newTitle: Impact of C-Reactive Protein Levels on Hospitalized COVID-19 Patients with Comorbidities

title: DNA repair may determine how cancer cells die following radiotherapy - The Tribune India
How powdered milk affects your child’s health and what to do about it - The Indian Express
summary:
How Powdered Milk Affects Your Child’s Health and What to Do About It

Publication Date: Not Specified Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses the potential health impacts of powdered milk on children, including risks associated with its consumption and healthier alternatives.

  • Powdered milk is dehydrated regular milk, retaining minerals but lacking certain enzymes.
  • Oxidised cholesterol from powdered milk processing may contribute to future heart disease and inflammation.
  • While not dangerous, powdered milk may lack the benefits of fresh milk.
  • Research suggests powdered milk may increase the risk of Type 2 diabetes in children.
  • Flavoured powdered milk products high in added sugars may lead to insulin resistance.
  • Regular consumption can stress a child's pancreas due to rapid blood sugar increases.
  • Fresh whole milk (organic or A2) is a better alternative for children.
  • Plant-based milk alternatives, if balanced in sugar and nutrients, can also be healthy options.
“Research indicates that early childhood nutritional practices, such as consuming powdered milk, may raise the risk of Type 2 diabetes.”

In conclusion, the article emphasizes the importance of choosing fresh milk options or carefully selected plant-based alternatives for children's health.
newTitle: How Powdered Milk Affects Your Child’s Health

title: Incurable 'Zombie Deer' disease may infect humans: All you need to know about this terrifying illness with - The Economic Times
Is Obesity in Children With Cancer Tied to Worse Survival? - Medscape
summary:
Is Obesity in Children With Cancer Tied to Worse Survival?

Publication Date: Not specified   Source: Cancer

Overall, obesity at the time of cancer diagnosis is independently associated with worse survival outcomes in pediatric patients.

Key Points:

  • The research indicates that obesity adversely affects outcomes in various pediatric cancers.
  • A study of 11,291 pediatric patients analyzed survival outcomes based on obesity status.
  • Key findings showed significant associations between obesity and survival rates, particularly in acute lymphoblastic leukemia and CNS tumors.
  • In children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, those with obesity had significantly lower survival rates.
  • No significant associations were found in lymphomas or non-CNS solid tumors.

Notable Quotes:

“Although obesity at cancer diagnosis was independently associated with inferior survival across the entire cohort, this finding was likely driven by the trends detected in children with ALL [acute lymphoblastic leukemia] and CNS tumors,” - Authors of the study.

Conclusion:

Obesity in pediatric cancer patients significantly affects survival, particularly in specific cancer types, highlighting the need for tailored care strategies.
newTitle: Is Obesity in Children With Cancer Tied to Worse Survival?

title: Characteristics and long-term health outcomes of the first domestic COVID-19 outbreak cases in Da Nang, Vietnam: a longitudinal cohort study - Tropical Medicine and Health
summary:
Characteristics and long-term health outcomes of the first domestic COVID-19 outbreak cases in Da Nang, Vietnam: a longitudinal cohort study

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: Tropical Medicine and Health

This study explores the characteristics and long-term health outcomes of patients involved in the first COVID-19 outbreak in Vietnam, which occurred in Da Nang in July 2020, revealing significant long-term health issues among survivors.

  • A total of 362 cases were studied, with a mortality rate of approximately 6% linked to underlying conditions.
  • By follow-ups at 6 and 16 months, 72.0% and 63.5% of survivors reported ongoing COVID-related symptoms, respectively.
  • Results indicated that females and older adults were more likely to report long COVID symptoms compared to males.
  • Common follow-up symptoms included cough, sleeping problems, and muscle pain, with varying prevalence over time.
"In the first domestic COVID-19 outbreak in Vietnam, the mortality rate was approximately 6% and associated with underlying medical conditions."

This study highlights the substantial long-term health issues faced by COVID-19 survivors and emphasizes the need for ongoing health assessments and support for this population.
newTitle: Long-term Health Outcomes from the First COVID-19 Outbreak in Da Nang, Vietnam: A Study

title: Sero-molecular prevalence of toxoplasmosis in hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis patients in Markazi Province, Iran - Tropical Medicine and Health
summary:
Sero-molecular prevalence of toxoplasmosis in hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis patients in Markazi Province, Iran

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: Tropical Medicine and Health

The study investigates the prevalence of latent toxoplasmosis in hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis patients in Markazi Province, Iran, highlighting significant findings regarding infection rates and age demographics.

This study analyzed 181 patients, finding 67.95% were seropositive for IgG antibodies, particularly in those over 60 years of age. No patients tested positive for IgM antibodies or T. gondii DNA. These results necessitate routine screenings for this vulnerable population.

  • 181 patients studied: 168 hemodialysis, 13 peritoneal dialysis.
  • 67.95% seroprevalence for IgG antibodies.
  • No positive IgM or T. gondii DNA results.
  • Higher prevalence in patients over 60 years.
  • Regular screening recommended for dialysis patients.
"The high prevalence of latent toxoplasmosis in dialysis patients underscores the need for regular screening to prevent serious complications."

This study provides important insights into the need for effective screening methods in managing infectious diseases among patients undergoing dialysis treatment.
newTitle: High Prevalence of Toxoplasmosis Among Dialysis Patients in Iran

title: 1 in 10 dads struggles with postpartum depression: Signs to watch out for, tips to address PPD in men - Hindustan Times
summary:
1 in 10 dads struggles with postpartum depression: Signs to watch out for, tips to address PPD in men

Publication Date: Not Specified Source: Hindustan Times

The article discusses the increasing acknowledgment of postpartum depression (PPD) in fathers, revealing that 1 in 10 men experience significant depression following their child's birth.

Key Points:

  • New research highlights that PPD is not exclusive to mothers.
  • The study indicates a correlation between pre-birth depression and postnatal depression in fathers.
  • Self-care and strong pre-birth well-being can mitigate the risk of PPD.
  • Common signs of PPD in dads include persistent sadness, difficulty bonding, and withdrawal from loved ones.
  • Expert recommendations for addressing PPD include open communication and professional help.

Notable Quotes:

“Many men internalise their struggles until it affects their marriage, relationships, or job performance.” - Shanaz Ikonne
“Fathers often feel unseen or unsupported in their mental health struggles.” - Dr. Nicole Monteiro

This article emphasizes the importance of recognizing PPD in fathers and suggests creating supportive environments that encourage open discussions about mental health in the context of fatherhood.
newTitle: 1 in 10 dads struggles with postpartum depression: Signs to watch out for, tips to address PPD in men

title: Deep-learning model based on MRI data predicts prostate cancer risk - AuntMinnie Europe
summary:
Deep Learning Model Predicts Prostate Cancer Progression Risk

Published on: 10 January 2023 | Source: Radiology: Imaging Cancer

A Dutch study demonstrates the effectiveness of a deep-learning model utilizing MRI data for predicting prostate cancer progression, potentially reducing unnecessary biopsies.

  • The model leverages MRI and clinical parameters to enhance risk assessment accuracy.
  • The study involved 1,607 MRI scans from 1,143 male patients.
  • It outperformed traditional risk calculators in predicting clinically significant cancer progression.
“Our proposed method could help to reduce the overuse of biopsies and MRI by guiding follow-up frequency in low-risk prostate cancer surveillance.” - Christian Roest, Data Scientist

The findings suggest that deep learning can improve patient-specific risk estimates and enhance surveillance strategies for prostate cancer.
newTitle: Deep Learning Model Predicts Prostate Cancer Progression Risk

Researchers develop nasal swab test to diagnose asthma in children - India TV News
summary:
Researchers Develop Nasal Swab Test to Diagnose Asthma in Children

Publication Date: January 2025 | Source: JAMA

A recent study published in the journal JAMA reveals that researchers have developed a nasal swab test for children that can help diagnose certain asthma subtype or endotype. This non-invasive approach can assist clinicians in prescribing treatments tailored for different subtypes of childhood asthma.

  • The study involved data from three U.S.-based studies focusing on Puerto Rican and African American youths, who have higher asthma rates.
  • Senior author Dr. Juan Celedón emphasized the need for new therapies to better treat Black and Puerto Rican children with asthma.
  • The research included nasal samples from 459 youths, analyzing the expression of eight T2 and T17 signature genes.
  • Results showed that 23%-29% of participants had T2 high, 35%-47% had T17-high, and 30%-38% had low-low endotype.
  • Dr. Celedón noted the potential for this rapid test to enhance research on asthma treatments.
"Asthma is the most common chronic disease of childhood, and it disproportionately affects Black and Puerto Rican children, so it's essential that we develop new therapies to better treat these young patients." - Dr. Juan Celedón

This nasal swab test represents a significant advancement in the diagnosis and treatment of asthma in children, paving the way for targeted therapies for various endotypes.
newTitle: Researchers Develop Nasal Swab Test to Diagnose Asthma in Children

title: Male infertility: How specialised IVF techniques improve sperm quality, chances of conception - Moneycontrol
summary:
Male infertility: How specialised IVF techniques improve sperm quality, chances of conception

Date: January 14, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

Male infertility presents significant challenges, but specialized IVF techniques are providing hope to couples aspiring for parenthood. These advancements play a crucial role in improving sperm quality and the chances of conception.

  • Male infertility accounts for nearly 40–50% of infertility cases.
  • IVF techniques, such as ICSI, focus on improving sperm quality.
  • These methods allow specialists to select the healthiest sperm for fertilization.
  • Precision techniques minimize fertilization risks and enhance success rates.
“One of IVF’s key strengths lies in its ability to isolate and work with the healthiest gametes... This approach minimises the risk of failed fertilization.” - Dr. Nishi Singh, Head of Fertility, Prime IVF

This ongoing evolution in IVF technology represents not just a medical solution but a hopeful pathway to parenthood for many couples facing male infertility.
newTitle: How IVF Techniques are Enhancing Male Fertility

title: Sierra Leone declares emergency over mpox outbreak - Al Jazeera English
Symptoms of HMPV infection: Here’s how to spot the signs, stay protected - Moneycontrol
summary:
Symptoms of HMPV infection: Here’s how to spot the signs, stay protected

Date: January 14, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

HMPV is a respiratory virus that can affect people of all ages, causing symptoms similar to the common cold or flu. Here are some preventive measures that can help reduce the risk of contracting HMPV and limit its spread.

  • HMPV has been detected in different parts of India, with a total of 17 reported cases.
  • The virus affects both children and adults, with mild symptoms in most cases.
  • In vulnerable groups, it can lead to severe illnesses like pneumonia or bronchitis.
  • Key symptoms include cough, fever, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, and headaches.
  • Severe symptoms may include wheezing, difficulty breathing, chest pain, dizziness, extreme fatigue, dehydration, and a persistent fever.
“People infected with HMPV usually experience cold or flu-like symptoms.” - World Health Organization

It is crucial to stay informed about HMPV and its associated symptoms to enhance public health safety and awareness.
newTitle: How to Identify and Protect Against HMPV Infection

title: Things you need to do if you’re diagnosed with pre-diabetes - The Indian Express
summary:
Things You Need to Do If You’re Diagnosed with Pre-Diabetes

Publication Date: Not specified

Source: The Indian Express

Prediabetes is a manageable illness that can be controlled with lifestyle modifications such as a nutrient-dense diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean meats, and healthy fats, as well as avoiding sugary and processed foods.

  • Engage in strength training and 150–180 minutes of moderate exercise per week to enhance insulin sensitivity.
  • Focus on weight management, aiming to lose 5–7% of body weight for better insulin sensitivity.
  • Monitor blood glucose levels regularly to make informed dietary and lifestyle choices.
  • Ensure 7 to 8 hours of sleep each night and practice stress-reduction techniques.
  • Adopt a holistic approach to prevent type 2 diabetes and reduce the risk of heart disease.
“Preventing the development of type 2 diabetes and lowering the risk of associated disorders like heart disease can be achieved by taking proactive measures.”

By implementing small, sustainable lifestyle changes, individuals can improve both short-term and long-term health outcomes.
newTitle: Things You Need to Do If You’re Diagnosed with Pre-Diabetes

title: Causes of dementia: Genetics, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity are high risk factor - Moneycontrol
summary:
Understanding the Causes of Dementia: Key Risks and Preventive Measures

Publication Date: July 30, 2024
Source: Moneycontrol

Dementia is a progressive condition that affects memory, concentration, and judgment, significantly impacting daily life. While aging plays a major role, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, and genetic factors are critical contributors.

  • A recent study indicates that 42% of Americans over 55 are at risk of dementia, a significant rise from previous estimates.
  • Women have a higher risk of 48% compared to men's 35%, largely due to longer lifespans.
  • The expected number of new dementia cases in the U.S. is half a million this year, potentially reaching one million annually by 2060.
“Dementia is becoming a critical public health issue.”

In conclusion, understanding the risk factors and preventive measures is essential in combating the rise of dementia cases, emphasizing the need for health awareness and lifestyle changes.
newTitle: Understanding the Causes of Dementia: Key Risks and Preventive Measures

Ajwain, also known as carom seeds, offers numerous health benefits, particularly in aiding digestion and promoting weight loss.

10 fibre-packed foods for a strong immune system, healthy gut - Moneycontrol
summary:

Man goes to doctor for toothache, leaves with a shocking prostate cancer diagnosis - Hindustan Times
summary:
Man Shocked by Prostate Cancer Diagnosis After Dental Visit

Date: Jan 14, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

A 78-year-old man went to his dentist for tooth pain and was later diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer after experiencing jaw swelling from a tooth extraction.

  • Swelling in the jaw after tooth removal led to further examination.
  • A CT scan revealed a lesion indicating metastatic prostate cancer.
  • This rare condition can occur when prostate cancer cells spread to the jaw.
  • Symptoms of jaw metastases may mimic dental issues.
Dr. Andrej Bozic stated, "Prostate cancer, like many other cancers, can metastasise to the jaw."

Prostate cancer is a significant health concern, affecting many globally, with around 400,000 deaths each year.
newTitle: Man Shocked by Prostate Cancer Diagnosis After Dental Visit

title: Study finds fibre in diet can help protect the body from infections - India TV News
Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide - Medscape
summary:
Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Medscape

This article discusses the alarming rise of HIV infections among women, particularly young cisgender women and those over 50. It highlights the barriers to accessing preventive measures and the innovative approaches being developed to improve care and adherence.

Key Points:

  • 4000 young cisgender women aged 15-24 contract HIV globally each week.
  • Women aged 50+ experiencing an increase in HIV infections.
  • Awareness and access to HIV preventive measures like PrEP and PEP are severely limited.
  • Misperceptions about personal risk and lack of healthcare provider guidance contribute to low adoption of prevention methods.
  • Innovative prophylactic options, including long-acting injectables and vaginal rings, show promise.
“Despite barriers to PrEP and PEP implementation among women, success stories from around the world show that these challenges can be overcome.”

In conclusion, integrating comprehensive HIV prevention strategies into healthcare systems can significantly improve outcomes for women globally.
newTitle: Innovations in HIV Care for Women Worldwide
